title: Funding NPR
story: Many listeners enjoy NPR broadcasts but never donate. Individuals benefit while avoiding the small personal cost of supporting the collective good. One day, you're listening to your favorite podcast and they ask you to donate $10. What do you do?

title: R&D Expenditures
story: Division heads vote on R&D funding. Everyone knows long-term survival depends on R&D, but the payoff is far in the future and budgets are tight now.

title: Splitting the Bill
story: A group agrees to split the dinner bill evenly. Each person could order something expensive, spreading the cost to everyone—unless everyone does it. The waiter comes to you for your order. What do you do?

title: International Business Ethics
story: A board considers leaving a market due to human rights violations. Leaving reduces profits; staying may fund unethical actors. What if the other firm stays? The vote comes down to you and your coworker. Without knowing what your coworker is going to say, what do you do?

title: Nuclear Energy and the Environment
story: Nuclear power produces large amounts of clean energy, but accidents and radioactive waste pose serious risks. Your country must decide whether to expand nuclear energy, knowing others are making similar decisions. What do you do?

title: The Digital Divide
story: Access to technology improves education and job opportunities, but expanding access costs money. Some regions invest heavily, while others wait and benefit indirectly. Your region is deciding whether to invest. What do you do?

title: Animal Testing and Ethics
story: Animal testing can speed up medical breakthroughs, but raises ethical concerns about animal welfare. Research labs must decide whether to continue animal testing while competitors make their own choices. What do you do?

title: Automation and Job Loss
story: Automation increases efficiency but can displace workers. Companies can invest in retraining or focus solely on automation. You must decide your company’s approach without knowing what competitors will do. What do you do?

title: Online Piracy
story: Movies, music, and books are easy to access online for free. Paying supports creators, but skipping payment saves money. You are deciding how to access content, knowing others face the same choice. What do you do?

title: Sustainable Agriculture
story: Sustainable farming reduces climate impact but costs more upfront. Farmers benefit most if many adopt these practices, but switching alone can be risky. You must decide your approach. What do you do?

title: Cybersecurity and Internet Freedom
story: Strong online surveillance can prevent cyber attacks, but it also limits privacy and freedom. Governments must decide their policies without knowing how strict others will be. What do you do?

title: Gig Economy and Worker Protections
story: Gig work offers flexibility but lacks benefits like healthcare and job security. Companies can improve protections, but doing so costs money. You must decide your company’s policy. What do you do?

title: Antibiotic Overuse
story: Antibiotics save lives, but overuse leads to resistant bacteria. Doctors must decide whether to prescribe antibiotics now or hold back for long-term safety. What do you do?

title: Gentrification
story: New development can improve a neighborhood but may displace long-term residents. City leaders must decide whether to encourage rapid development or slow it down. What do you do?

title: Free University Education
story: Offering free university education benefits society but requires higher taxes. Citizens must decide whether to support the policy, knowing others are making the same choice. What do you do?

title: Deforestation
story: Clearing rainforest land helps farmers support their families but worsens climate change. Farmers must decide whether to preserve trees or clear land, knowing others face the same choice. What do you do?

title: Overharvesting Fish
story: Fishing companies see catches decline but continue to fish heavily to maximize profits today. If everyone fishes less, stocks could recover. What do you do?

title: Watering the Lawn
story: During a drought, residents are asked not to water their lawns. Letting your lawn die looks bad, but if everyone cooperates water shortages ease. What do you do?

title: Insurance Fraud
story: Filing a dishonest insurance claim can bring quick money, but widespread fraud raises premiums for everyone. You are deciding how honest to be. What do you do?
